text: Please change the show dependents screen for blogs to not link to the blog settings but to link to the live blog instead, or atleast have a button on that settings page to go to the blog’s listing page.

related to a slack that <@U26BLKGE4> brought up a while ago about Content based membership features of HubSpot (that is only available for Marketing Enterprise) - would people be interested in it if it was an Add-on that someone could purchase separately? I'm working on an Idea ticket for this but want to see if there is already some initial interest

[edit] For those who are interested, here is the link to the idea: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Include-Membership-Content-tool-as-an-Add-on/idi-p/250788>

Would love an upvote if you find it helpful and let's see if we can get this added!
Absolutely, we have clients that are not enterprise tier that wanted similar functionality and we had to roll our own or use a different service for the membership side.
I’ve also seen several devs on here ask about a feature like this then go :disappointed: when they find out the portal they’re working on can’t use that feature.
Agreed, we have clients that need a membership site but dont have the money for enterprise. Also with the standalone CMS being an option now, this needs to happen
Jon and AJ, rock on, thanks! I just inlcuded the link in the original message in case you want to go upvote it
definitely a great idea, and I think it would be a popular product. Having a membership area that natively integrates with the CRM opens up a world of possibility
few things...

1) Would this be different than our CMS? Aka: To keep it simple, do you need protected content without say a nav? So it would be its own add-on? Or you'd buy the CMS and THEN buy the restricted content add-on too?
2) What would you expect to pay for something like this?
you’d have to buy the cms or have a plan, THEN buy memberships
more likely the buy CMS, then buy the Membership add-on
cc <@UBRAL1DLY>
price wise it definitely has to be cheaper than  the CMS addon itself since it’s a subset of additional features.

It would be hard to say what to expect with pricing as some open sourced (like WP, Joomla, Drupal) all have this as do the paid ones. Honesty, I get having to have people pay more for more features but I feel like with the amount of CMS platforms out there that just include this, it might be more of a deterrent than attraction if you made it an addon

Tackle it this way... if you had a path to have this feature in the $300 version, what would you recommend for an enterprise version of the CMS. Blue sky, any suggestions are welcome :slightly_smiling_face:
That’s a pretty valid point
so regarding what features the enterprise CMS had - <@U26BLKGE4> found a big pain point this morning regarding subscription pages

When i think "Enterprise" CMS, I am thinking of platforms like EpiServer or ExpressionEngine, ones where you get a selfhosted option that can be installed on AWS or something like that, when I think SaaS Enterprise, thats where you are going more with the Hosted WP, Hosted Umbraco and so on.
re Jon's point, I'll post in the primary channel
The only thing for a CMS add-on that I can see being paid for (outside the $300) would be Ecommerce

Ran into an issue this morning with an enterprise client where their built-in HS subscription pages could not be segmented by brand domain. So customers who converted on one domain were being taken to a completely differently branded subscription page. Are there any plans to update this in the future?

This client wants all contacts in one CRM, but obviously their subscription preferences should be able to be segmented per domain.

See, I'm not sure I agree there. The issue with talking about HubSpot as a "CMS" is that it really isn't in the traditional sense. It's simultaneously a CMS AND SaaS AND managed hosting. In that sense, I'm ok with premium addons, and honestly for this kind of customer, I think it's reasonable to charge close to, if not the same amount as, the standalone CMS. The functionality needs to be there to support that price point, but I could see it selling, and saving us devs a lot of time avoiding building our own apps to support these use-cases
Otherwise, we're back at the point where is enterprise worth it VS just having multiple HS Pro contracts?
True, I would say if the standalone included memberships and everything we get now, $350 - $400/mn would be good to me.

I'm also of the mindset that charging the same amount for membership as the CMS, though I totally understand Jon's point about it being a subfeature of the CMS. This is a more complicated feature that has immense capabilities and is something so many websites use

I’d say AJ’s point about most CMS’s having this by default is kind of a good point as to why it should not cost substantially more or == to the standalone CMS.

AJ’s suggestion of memberships being rolled into standalone, and just being a higher price point, is pretty reasonable and makes it easier to sell clients on

Agreed on that, its much easier to say to a client that you get all the best things for one price then say you can get this but.... to have this, extra. Makes it appear that HS is just trying to nickle and dime
Ah, misread AJ's message. Yeah, including content membership by default with the CMS and then increasing base price makes a lot of sense to me

I guess my main concern in this route though are the number of clients that we don't get the CMS addon for but still have the conversations about membership content (and something that a form redirect or global password wouldn't accomplish). That's why I'd still be interested in membership as an addon instead of rolled into the CMS
maybe I’m missing something but how would you have membership WITHOUT the CMS, seems like that would defy the point.

Jon, great question, I guess the main confusion is on my end - that being we get our accounts on Marketing Pro but don't get the $300 CMS add-on. That was actually my main confusion was trying to figure out what the CMS actually gives me that Marketing Pro doesn't already (besides HubDB and I guess an additional subdomain/content type).
Unless it was a standalone membership app that could be used with any frontend, but that would be a whole new product for HS to make
<@UDFSF3N1F> I was meaning That the feature would just be part of the CMS, so any plan involving the CMS gets memberships too
Thus if you only had memberships you couldn’t do anything with that as you couldn’t create pages or landing pages or anything that used it
Jon, yep totally get that. I have a feeling I'm just interpreting CMS differently than how it should be and am just getting caught up in the technicalities
CMS = all forms of front end pages and blogs

Yeah, making sense now. I was strictly operating under the mindset of CMS being the CMS add-on by HubSpot and not the more general CMS form. Apologies for the disconnect and thanks for the clarification

requested this before but would be nice if `require_js` supported adding parameters to the script tag.

Example output:
`<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/magnific-popup.js/1.0.0/jquery.magnific-popup.min.js" integrity="sha256-B4XiskM8tpRyptxx0sb2SljXOqBzXKSDi18CI7NomLY=" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>`

Would be nice to be able to add integrity and crossorigin.

would also make HS sites more easily able to be secure
Allow help text to be toggled between showing a button or having it inline below the label. Example:
or even both
meaning help text and like “description text” as separate fields/things
that could work as well
